bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In these rules:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: access order means an order under section 49 (2) of the Act authorizing either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: someone from a designated agency to enter premises and to interview the adult;
a health care provider to enter premises to examine the adult to determine whether health care should be provided;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Adult Guardianship Act;
adult means a person who is the subject of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an investigation described in section 47 (3) (d) of the Act, or
an application under section 51 (1) (e) or 54 of the Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: assessment particulars means the written details and results of an assessment provided under section 6 of the Adult Guardianship (Abuse and Neglect) Regulation, B.C. Reg. 13/2000;
assessment report means an incapability assessment report in the form required under section 6 of the Adult Guardianship (Abuse and Neglect) Regulation, B.C. Reg. 13/2000;
clerk means a member of the registry staff;
designated agency means any public body, organization or person that, under the Designated Agencies Regulation, B.C. Reg. 76/2000, is designated as an agency for the purposes of Part 3 of the Act;
interim restraining order means an order made under section 51 (1) (e) of the Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicant,
the adult,
each respondent, and
anyone the court decides is a party;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: registry means a registry of the court where family matters are dealt with;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an application for an access order, the adult,
in the case of an application for an interim restraining order, both the person against whom the order is sought and the adult,
in the case of an application for a support and assistance order or a restraining order, each person listed in section 54 (2) of the Act,
in the case of an application to renew, change or cancel an existing order, the person who applied for, and each person who was required to be served with, the application for the existing order, and
in the case of any other application, the person named as the respondent in the application;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: restraining order means an order made under section 56 (3) (c) of the Act;
support and assistance order means an order made under section 56 (3) (a), (d) or (e) of the Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The purpose of these rules is to allow decisions about matters arising under Part 3 of the Act [Support and Assistance for Abused and Neglected Adults] to be obtained from the court as fairly, quickly and inexpensively as possible.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for access orders
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an access order, a designated agency must complete an application in Form 1 and file with the court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the completed application, and
an affidavit setting out the facts on which the application is based.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for interim restraining orders
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an interim restraining order, a designated agency must complete an application in Form 1 and file with the court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the completed application,
an affidavit setting out the facts on which the application is based, and
if section 51 (2) of the Act does not apply, a draft notice to appear in Form 2 to the person against whom the order is sought.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for support and assistance orders and restraining orders
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for a support and assistance order, a restraining order or both, a designated agency must complete an application in Form 1 and file with the court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the completed application,
a support and assistance plan that complies with section 54 (3) (a) of the Act,
unless the only order being sought is a restraining order, the assessment particulars relating to the adult,
unless the only order being sought is a restraining order, an assessment report relating to the adult, and
in addition, if a restraining order is sought, a draft notice to appear in Form 2 to the person against whom the order is sought.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Where to file an application under subrule (1), (2) or (3)
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application for an order referred to in subrule (1), (2) or (3) must be filed in the registry closest to the adult's habitual residence unless a judge permits otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for renewal, variation or cancellation of support and assistance orders
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order renewing, changing or cancelling a support and assistance order, a designated agency must complete an application in Form 3 and file with the court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the completed application, and
if the need for the existing order was reviewed under section 57 of the Act, a report on the review.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for variation or cancellation of an existing restraining order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order changing or cancelling a restraining order, the person against whom that order was made must complete an application in Form 3 and file the completed application with the court.
An application for an order, other than an order referred to in subrule (1), (2) or (3), must be filed in the registry where the file is located, unless a judge permits otherwise.
A judge may conduct a hearing or part of a hearing by telephone in appropriate circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Some applications may be granted without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may make the following orders without a hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under Rule 7 (8) permitting another method of service;
an order under Rule 9 (3) (a) waiving or modifying a time limit set by these rules or the court;
an order under Rule 9 (3) (b) waiving or modifying any service or notice requirement of these rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: To apply for an order, except a consent order, without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for an order to be made under subrule (9), a party must complete an application in Form 4 and file with the court under subrule (7)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the completed application, and
an affidavit setting out the facts on which the application is based.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: To apply for a consent order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for a consent order, a person must complete an application in Form 5 and file with the court under subrule (7)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the completed application,
a draft consent order in Form 6 containing the particulars of the order sought, and
an affidavit setting out the facts on which the application is based.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may sign consent order or require parties to attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A clerk must place the application, draft consent order and supporting documents before a judge who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if satisfied that consent is given and that it is appropriate to make the order, may approve and sign the consent order without the parties having to attend, or
may direct that the parties and any other person specified by the judge attend before the judge to explain why the order should be made.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of appearance if parties required to attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a direction is given under subrule (12) (b), a clerk must notify the parties and any other person specified by the judge of the date, time and place for the court appearance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: To apply for other orders requiring a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To apply for cancellation of a subpoena or for any procedural order or direction not mentioned in this rule, a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must complete an application in Form 4 and file the completed application with the court under subrule (7), and
may file with the application an affidavit setting out the facts on which the application is based.

bcl:text.in:em: [For service of applications, see sections 51 (2) and 54 (2) of the Act and Rule 7.]

bcl:rule.bcl:text: First and Subsequent Appearances in Court

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Except in the case of an application for an order referred to in Rule 2 (9) or (11), a clerk must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set the date, time and place for hearing the application, and
enter those details on the application form before it is accepted for filing and on any notice to appear issued under subrule (2) relating to the application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Issue of notice to appear if interim or other restraining order is sought
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a draft notice to appear (Form 2) is filed with an application for an interim restraining order or a restraining order, a clerk must complete the notice to appear and issue it to the applicant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of notice to appear if interim or other restraining order is sought
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless permission is granted under Rule 7 (8) to use a different method of service or section 51 (2) of the Act applies,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: both a notice to appear issued under subrule (2) and the related application for the interim restraining order or the restraining order must, within 72 hours after the filing of the application, be personally served on the person against whom the order is sought, and
the applicant must arrange to have the notice to appear and the related application served on the adult in accordance with paragraph (a) by an individual who is at least 19 years of age.

bcl:text.in:em: [For service of applications, see sections 51 (2) and 54 (2) of the Act and Rule 7.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The judge at the first appearance or any subsequent appearance may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order a party to allow another party to inspect and copy records, specified in the order, that are or have been in that other party's possession or control or, if not in that other party's possession or control, are within the other party's power;
hear evidence and make the order sought in the application;
make any other order or give any direction that the judge considers appropriate.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the respondent does not appear in court
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a respondent fails to appear in court on the date and at the time and place specified on a document served on the respondent under the Act or these rules, or as directed by a judge, a judge may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: draw any inference from that failure that the judge considers appropriate, including an inference that the respondent consents to the order sought by the applicant;
if the judge considers that the circumstances justify it and that it is fair to do so in the respondent's absence, make the order sought by the applicant;
issue a notice to appear in Form 2 to be served on the respondent;

if the respondent was personally served with a notice to appear on that date and at that time or was present in court when the date for the court appearance was set, issue a warrant in Form 7 for the arrest of the respondent.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long a warrant is in force
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A warrant under subrule (5) (d) remains in force until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the respondent named in the warrant appears in court either voluntarily or under the warrant, or
a justice cancels the warrant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A respondent who is arrested under a warrant must be brought before a justice as soon as practicable.
The justice must release the respondent on giving the respondent a release in Form 8 requiring the respondent to appear in court on the date and at the time and place stated in the release.
A clerk must notify the applicant regarding the date, time and place of the appearance stated in the release.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If respondent does not comply with release
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the respondent does not appear in court on the date and at the time stated on the release, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a warrant in Form 7 for the arrest of the respondent and order that the respondent be brought to a judge promptly on that arrest, or
do anything described in subrule (5) (a) or (b).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To require a witness to attend court, a party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a subpoena in Form 9, and
serve a copy of the subpoena on the witness personally at least 7 days before the date the witness is required to appear.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At the time the subpoena is served, the party subpoenaing the witness must offer the witness reasonable estimated travelling expenses.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a witness served with a subpoena must do
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a subpoena must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: appear in court on the date and at the time and place stated on the subpoena, and
bring to court any records and other things required by the subpoena.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Not less than 2 days before the date a person served with a subpoena is to appear in court, the person may apply under Rule 2 (14) to a judge who may cancel the subpoena if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is not needed as a witness, or
it would be a hardship for the person to appear in court as required by the subpoena.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a witness does not obey a subpoena
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may issue a warrant in Form 7 for the arrest of a witness who does not appear in court as required by a subpoena if the judge is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the subpoena was served on the witness,
reasonable travelling expenses were offered to the witness, and
justice requires the presence of the witness.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long a warrant for arrest of witness is in force
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A warrant remains in force until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the witness named in the warrant appears in court either voluntarily or under the warrant, or
a judge cancels the warrant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A witness who is arrested under a warrant must be brought before a judge or justice of the peace as soon as practicable.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge may do when the witness appears
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the witness's evidence is still required, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: release the witness on giving the witness a release in Form 8 requiring the witness to appear in court on the date and at the time and place stated in the release, or
order a sheriff or peace officer to detain the witness in custody until the witness's presence is no longer required.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may make the release of a witness under subrule (8) (a) subject to any conditions respecting reporting or residency or entering into a recognizance that the judge considers necessary to make sure the witness attends.
At a hearing, evidence may be given orally or, unless the judge orders otherwise, by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: affidavit, or
statements of facts agreed to by the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Oral evidence may be given by a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under oath or affirmation, or
if section 5 (3) of the Evidence Act applies, on the person promising to tell the truth.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person who is served with an application does not appear in court on the date and at the time and place set for the hearing, the judge may hear the application and make the order applied for if the judge thinks it is fair to do so in that person's absence.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Advance notice of experts' evidence required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may call an expert to give evidence of the expert's opinion, but only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party provides a written summary of the expert's evidence to all other parties at least 30 days before the expert is called to give evidence, or
a judge grants permission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Experts' reports must be given in advance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Instead of calling an expert to give evidence, a party may introduce a report stating opinions of an expert, but only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party provides a copy of the report to all other parties at least 30 days before the report is introduced, or
a judge grants permission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A designated agency and an assessor authorized under the Adult Guardianship (Abuse and Neglect) Regulation are not experts for the purposes of notice under subrule (4) or (5).
A statement of qualifications in an expert's report is proof that the expert has those qualifications unless there is evidence to the contrary.
A report stating the opinions of an expert may be introduced without proof of the expert's signature.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Experts may be called for cross-examination
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party receiving another party's expert report may serve on the other party, at least 14 days before the hearing date, a notice requiring the expert to attend the hearing for cross-examination.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cost of calling other party's expert
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge determines that calling another party's expert was unnecessary, the judge may order the party who required the expert to attend to pay to the other party the reasonable costs associated with the expert's attendance.
If an affidavit is permitted under these rules, it must be in Form 10.
Any exhibits referred to in an affidavit must be identified and attached to the affidavit.
With the permission of the judge, an affidavit may be used in evidence even though it does not comply in form with this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Affidavit must be filed and served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Evidence may be given by affidavit at a hearing only if, at least 7 days before the date of the hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: copies of the affidavit are filed in the registry, and
a copy of the affidavit is served on everyone who is entitled to notice of the hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If evidence is given by affidavit, the judge may, at the request of a party or on the judge's own motion, order that the deponent attend the court for cross-examination.
Unless the Act or these rules provide otherwise, an application must be served at least 7 days before the date set for the hearing on the following persons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the application is for an interim restraining order and section 51 (2) of the Act does not apply, on the adult and the person against whom the order is sought;
if the application is for a support and assistance order or a restraining order, the persons required to be served under section 54 (2) of the Act;
if the application is to renew, change or cancel an existing order, the person who applied for, and the persons who were required to be served with, the application for the existing order;
in the case of an application other than one referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (c), on the other parties.

bcl:text.in:em: [See section 51 (2) of the Act for the circumstances in which service of an application for an interim restraining order is not required, and section 54 (2) of the Act for a list of persons who must be served with an application for a support and assistance order.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the application is for cancellation of a subpoena
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application for cancellation of a subpoena must be served, at least 2 days before the date the witness is to appear in court, on the party subpoenaing the witness.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Documents to be served with the application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The persons required to be served under subrule (1) or (2) must also be served, at the time the application is served, with a copy of each document filed under Rule 2 in support of the application, other than the assessment particulars.
Service of an application is not required if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application is for an order referred to in Rule 2 (9), or
a judge so orders.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: General rule about how documents may be served
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document required by the Act or these rules to be served may be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on an individual, including a party,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the individual,
by registered mail to the individual's last known postal address,
by faxing it, together with a fax cover page in Form 11, to the fax number provided by the individual, or
if the individual is a party who has a lawyer of record, by leaving a copy at, or by faxing it, together with a fax cover page in Form 11, to, that lawyer's office;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a designated agency, whether or not it is a society within the meaning of the Societies Act,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with a representative of that agency,
by registered mail to the agency's postal address, or
by faxing it, together with a fax cover page in Form 11, to the fax number provided by the agency;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a society within the meaning of the Societies Act, other than a designated agency,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: at the delivery address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies,
with a director or officer of the society, or
with a receptionist at the society's office;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by registered mail to the mailing address of the society's registered office on file with the Registrar of Companies, or
by faxing it, together with a fax cover page in Form 11, to the fax number provided by the society;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on any other person, including the Public Guardian and Trustee,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with a receptionist or other employee at that person's place of business,
by registered mail to the person's postal address,
by faxing it, together with a fax cover page in Form 11, to the fax number provided by the person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subrule (5) does not apply to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: service of a notice to appear;
service of an application for an interim restraining order or restraining order on the person against whom the order is sought;
service of a subpoena.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Personal service required for notice to appear
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless permission is granted under subrule (8) to use a different method of service,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice to appear issued under Rule 3 (5) (c) must be personally served on the respondent at least 7 days before the date of the hearing referred to in the notice, and
the applicant must arrange to have the notice to appear served in accordance with paragraph (a) by an individual who is at least 19 years of age.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Permission to use other service methods
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document cannot be served as provided in these rules or if the person to be served is temporarily outside British Columbia, a party may apply to a judge who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permit another method of service to be used, and
direct how service is to be proved.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document may be proved by filing the following at the registry:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for personal service of a document, a certificate of service (Form 12);
for service by registered mail, a certificate of service (Form 12), with attached to the certificate a copy of the document and one of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy, produced by fax or otherwise, of the signature obtained by Canada Post at the time the document was delivered;
a print out of the delivery confirmation made available on the Internet by Canada Post;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for personal service on a lawyer, a copy of the document signed by the lawyer or an articled student or by a partner or employee of the firm;
for service by fax, a certificate of service (Form 12) with a transmission report generated by the sending machine.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may require copy of served document
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may require that a copy of the served document be attached to the certificate of service (Form 12).
Instead of requiring proof of service under subrule (9), a judge or registrar may allow a person to prove by sworn oral evidence that the person has personally served a document.
An order takes effect on the day it was made by a judge unless the judge orders otherwise.
Any judge may correct, at any time, a clerical mistake in an order or a mistake arising from an accidental slip or omission.
An order must be prepared as soon as practicable and must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in Form 13 in the case of an access order,
in Form 14 in the case of an interim restraining order or a restraining order,
in Form 15 in the case of a support and assistance order,
in Form 16 in the case of an order renewing, changing or cancelling another order, and
in Form 17 in the case of any other order, except a consent order.

bcl:text.in:em: [Rule 2 (11) requires a consent order to be in Form 6.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The applicant must prepare the order unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the judge orders otherwise, or
the order is made under section 58 of the Act [change or cancellation of restraining order] and the applicant is not represented by a lawyer.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Clerk prepares the order for unrepresented party
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the judge orders otherwise, if the applicant for an order under section 58 of the Act is not represented by a lawyer, a clerk must, as soon as practicable, prepare the order in the applicable form.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Approving the form of the order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless a judge orders otherwise, an order that is prepared by a party's lawyer must be signed as approved

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the party's lawyer, and
if any other party is represented by a lawyer, by the other party's lawyer.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may apply to a judge to settle the terms of an order if there is a dispute about the terms.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Delivering the order to the registry
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After an order is signed as approved in accordance with subrule (6),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it must be delivered to the registry to be signed by a judge, filed with the court and date stamped with the registry stamp, and
any document required by a judge to be filed with the order must be delivered for filing at the same time, or the order ceases to have effect.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the judge orders otherwise, after an order is signed by the judge and filed with the court, a clerk must provide a filed copy of the order to the parties or their lawyers.
Whether or not the parties consent, a judge may adjourn a hearing to a specific date or without specifying a date.
A hearing may be adjourned only with the permission of a judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may shorten or extend time limits
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: waive or modify a time limit set by these rules or by an order of the court even after the time limit has expired;
waive or modify any service or notice requirement under these rules;
permit any other means of proof instead of that required by these rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may change or cancel an order made in the absence of a party who received notice of a hearing if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that party applies within a reasonable time,
the party had a good reason for failing to attend when the order was made,
there is a good reason for changing or cancelling the order, and
the change or cancellation would be in the adult's best interests.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Order may be made without notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may make an order without a person having been served with a copy of an application if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a matter is urgent or special circumstances exist, or
section 51 (2) of the Act applies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of proceedings and adding parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may, at any time, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that a person, whether or not a party, be given notice of a hearing;
order that a person be added as a party for purposes of a hearing or the proceedings generally;
dispense with a requirement that notice of a hearing be given to a person who is not a party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Powers that any judge may exercise
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any judge may do any of the following without being seized of a matter:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjourn a hearing before evidence is heard;
make orders or give directions on procedural matters.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge who starts a hearing must continue
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (9), a judge who has heard any evidence at a hearing must finish the hearing unless the judge dies or is otherwise unable to act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If judge cannot finish the hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge who has begun to hear evidence dies or is otherwise unable to act, another judge will hear the case and that judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: start the hearing again and re-hear all the evidence, or
with the consent of the parties, continue with the hearing where it left off, giving directions for hearing evidence as the judge considers necessary.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may give a direction on any procedural matter that is not provided for in the Act or these rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may order transfer of file
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may order a file transferred to another registry, for the purposes of one application or for all purposes, after considering

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the balance of convenience,
any special circumstances that exist, and
the adult's best interests.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the parties agree, a clerk may transfer a file to another registry, for the purposes of one application or for all purposes, if the parties

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complete a written and signed consent to the transfer, and
file the consent in the registry where the file is located.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: With the judge's permission, a copy of a document may be used in court instead of the original.
Only the following are entitled to search a registry file respecting a matter under the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party;
a party's lawyer;
a person authorized by a party, by a party's lawyer or by a judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not comply with the rules
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party does not comply with these rules, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cancel a step taken or an order made or disregard a document filed in the course of the application, or
make any order or give any direction that the judge thinks is fair, including an order dismissing the application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any document may be filed in a registry by faxing it to that registry, but a judge may require that the original of a document be filed later.
The forms in Appendix A are prescribed for the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Forms 1 to 17, for the purposes of these rules;
Form 18, for the purposes of section 49 (3) of the Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Forms generated by the user must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in substantial compliance with the prescribed forms, and
show the applicable words of the prescribed form in regular type and the words supplied by the user in boldface type.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The chief judge of the court may issue practice directions consistent with these rules and their purpose.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may order production of records
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On application, a judge may order a person who possesses or controls a record that is relevant to the proceedings and on whom notice has been served in accordance with Rule 7 (1) to produce the record for inspection and copying on the date, at the time and place and in the manner the judge thinks is fair.

reg:content.reg:provisionsnote: [Provisions relevant to the enactment of this regulation: Court Rules Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 80, s. 1 (2).]
